Lets start with the most obvious difference from an algorithm perspective that anyone with a CS education could tell you one uses locality sensitive hashing techniques like SimHash while the other uses neural networks with specific architectures transformer based is the standard. If thats too technical, then consider this one generates new derivative content based on an original corpus of data whereas the other retrieves content from elsewhere i.e. the web. Theres other complementary concepts for LLMs to discuss like RAG, but I cannot be bothered. Go ask ChatGPT, then go to Google Search to find actual credible sources for what is actually true ironically, ChatGPT will tell you to do that too without naming the search engine. Therein rests the answer.

What determines the aggregate of wealth is the inefficiencies in the market. eg if I were the only person who knew that the true odds of a coin flip were 5050, I would buy up all the bets undervalued 49 and under until all that were left were 5050 bets. So yes, by the end of that process it is the aggregate of wealth that determines the prices, what determines the aggregate of wealth is the inefficiencies in the market before it. A market that rewards accuracy tends to be very accurate, even if 99 of the bettors in the market are clueless

Yes there might be rare cases where the one person who knows all 11 secret herbs and spices doesnt tell anyone else and doesnt like making loads of money for themselves, but as that information is not out there in any tangible form its stuck in someones head who doesnt join the market, no other predictive model could also know that information and betting markets would still be the most accurate predictive system out there. We can only compare them to other current predictive models polling etc and in that sense they win resoundingly and the evidence is there to back that up, even if you dont fully understand the mechanism behind it.

replies.text: What about cost though? A one time treatment is great and all, but not when it costs 10x the price of existing treatments and arent much better.

That is the case with most gene editing treatments. We are in new era of specialty drugs. You are hitting upon a really crucial aspect though... financially, the rationale is that curing it via a one time treatment is more cost effective long term because it reduces costly activities incurred when flareups occur. An anecdote for this would be people with sickle cell are frequent fliers at emergency rooms and frequently on opioids or become addicted to pain mgmt drugs. Casgevy by CRISPR can cure them albeit for 3M. The second aspect is ethics. How could you deny access to patients suffering from life threatening or excruciating chronic diseases. Both this financial and ethical dynamics will need to be built into pricing these therapies, government intervention, and payer methodologies eventually.

I am unconvinced the market for widespread gene therapy is there. I fear this is a Concorde situation, where the technology is superior, but just isnt economically viable though from Intellia, their gene therapy isnt even better than existing treatments. Are health systems around the world really going to spend 3m per drug per patient to treat something that is perfectly manageable at a reasonable cost? This is especially true for niche diseases. I can see these drugs being offered if the disease is common enough but I still think its far too risky for an investor at the moment

Def a possibility, but neither of us have crystal ball so caveat is that this could be great investment if you are comfortable with high risk. Your Concorde example is not apples to apples. One a faster way to get from point A to point B and another is possibly life saving. Medicaid is only lucrative for payers bc the government stepped in. There is a solid chance the government will have to step in here as well and make it lucrative to inspire innovation and health equity

My concorde analogy wasnt comparing industry to industry, but to that of technology and economics. No, they arent. Pensions are far more efficient than 401ks, delivering the same payout in retirement with only 50 of the input cost. There are three big reasons for this 1 Actuarial savings. With a 401k, you must save enough money and limit withdrawal rates to a level low enough to last for your maximum potential lifespan. Defined benefit pensions only need to save enough for the average workers lifespan, because some people will die earlier and others will die later. This reduces the cost of a given future income by 30. 2 Reduced management fees, which save approximately 10. 3 With a 401k, your asset allocation must vary across your lifespan. When youre young you can maintain 100 equities, giving a high rate of return. However, you have virtually no money invested. Conversely, as you get older, you must add bonds to account for sequence of return risk, reducing your average rate of return during the time when you have the largest account balance. Pension funds can maintain an optimal asset allocation at all times, increasing the lifetime rate of return.

April 17, 2007 Sanofi pasteur, the vaccines division of the sanofiaventis Group, announced today that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration FDA has licensed its H5N1 vaccine, the first avian influenza vaccine for humans in the U.S. Sanofi pasteur, in collaboration with the National Institutes of Health, submitted a Biologics License Application to the FDA for this H5N1 vaccine. The licensure serves as a first key step in achieving the governments goal of stockpiling vaccine intended to protect those who are at increased risk of exposure to the H5N1 influenza virus contained in the vaccine during the early stages of a pandemic. Source FDA Licenses First U.S. Vaccine for Humans Against Avian Influenza

The insurance for the waste is one of the biggest prohibitions to nuclear waste. It essentially needs to be guaranteed forever, this results in the only ones willing to take the risk being states and countries.

It is not 75000 years to store waste. Low and intermediate level waste is stored for 30 years in cooldown pools before being buried is ceramic pucks, and hight level waste is stored for 50 years before being buried. High level waste loses 99.9 of its reactivity in 40 years. The worst high level waste is back to background level within 100010000 years. The Navy has stored all of its waste generated over the last 60 years of nuclear power in a single spent copper mine. 95 of waste is low level. 0.2 is high level, with intermediate making up the difference. 30 percent of all used fuel is reprocessed for reuse in reactors and a small percentage is refined for medical use. As for the cost. Long term storage for is estimated 10 of the total cost of the reactors lifetime expense, and is required by the government to be set aside to cover all costs.

Nuclear waste is an extremely over exagerated problem. The entirety of highly dangerous nuclear waste produced in France from the past 40 years fits into a single cube with sides measuring 15 meters. And Its the most nuclearized country in the world, and the total amount of carbon free energy produced for so little waste is absolutely outstanding.

The fear of another Chernobyl, TMI, etc... forced the industry to be regulated to the point that for most companies it wasnt financially viable. The company I work for used to own Talen energy mentioned in this article the reason it was sold off is because it was just dead weight back then. Perfect example...at the Susquehanna plant mentioned, we had to keep two fleets of excavators on hand in case of a meltdown and pay for upkeep, maintenance, etc... It was literally redundancy for a black swan event, wild. This is the reason that Exelon has basically been the name in the game in nuke generation in the US. My old boss used to head up exelons nuke operations the only way they were able to make it profitable was through acquisition and absolutely ruthless standardization...they acquired a new plant and would implement the playbook...execsemployees who pushed back were gone. Same service intervals, same vendors for IT systems, same schemes, same excavator, same everything across the entire fleet. My company, as many others have long said nuke is the answer...with reasonable regulation. SMR and the involvement of big tech is bringing that conversation to the forefront. Your fallacy is in attributing the causes of previous nuclear incidents all to operator error. Humans make mistakes, of course, and Chernobyl management was definitely negligent and reckless. However, what made Chernobyl a disaster was shoddy reactor design that wouldve never been possible in the West. I mean, hitting the shutdown reactor button is what caused the Chernobyl reactors to explode! Same goes to Fukushima with its backup generator design and way too tiny tsunami seawalls. Its not just the Wests operational practices that have made nuclear energy so safe here. Its that reactor facilities have been designed with passive safety in mind to prevent operator error from ever causing a disaster, and the next generation nuclear technology takes that to another level. Its like saying cars in the 50s were so dangerous because even minor accidents could kill or cause severe injury, so people just shouldnt drive. Sure, operators need to improve, but the cars themselves could get a whole lot safer, and they have!

replies.text: To me the real challenges are both legal and operational. So for fun, lets assume all Elons claims come true. 2030k in 2026 with FSD without lidar just for the sake of argument. Nobody has clearance to run fully autonomous cars on the road. There are some companies who have some clearance to run some cars and they are reporting back good data. But thats all based on lidar systems, not just camera based. The roll out will have to take this in consideration and this is not a technological step but a governance one. This will take considerable time. Beyond that, these cars will need charging, which might be inductive sure but that still needs infrastructure which needs to be built out. Since there is no single station built anywhere. Then you have to think about the hygiene within the car, both in terms of actual hygiene, but also gravity and misuse by the public. This will need operational staff too. This is where the waymo roll out is a lot more sensible, especially the partnership with a company like Uber who does have infrastructure and operational staff in most mayor cities or the capacity to scale. And even if you were to fix all of those issues youd also be activating a lot of latent demand for mobility, there is a reason you need a license to run a taxi in NYC otherwise it would be even more gridlocked than it is today. Now add into that mix every subway rider who now wants to take a cybertaxi. Walking would be faster at that rate. And that is just existing ridership, latent demand is real and will affect cities. This future increases call for regulation. The vision is clear and yes long term this will be how mobility will be operated. Along side many other options like autonomous busses, streetcars, trains and subways. Who knows if you are looking long term maybe even drones with more energy density from advanced solid state batteries. But for now they should focus on proving the concept and setting themselves up to scale, this course will only cause dissatisfaction with shareholders over unmet goals.

This is likely to get downvoted heavily. But I actually do not think Tesla is serious about a robot taxi service. I have not seen any investment specifically for such a service beyond the event. The cars are really for selling at some point in the future like they now have the S, X, 3, Y and Cybertruck. If they were serious about a robot taxi service they would be investing into getting permits, starting a trial, etc. All we have so far is them driving around in a very controlled environment without a driver. Everywhere else they have a driver as is required with FSD. Google also did a show like what Tesla did. But the difference is that Google did it just coming up on 10 years ago. It was done in early 2015. So basically a decade earlier. But also Google did their actually on public roads. Not a movie set. So a much more impressive demo. The problem for Tesla is that actually rolling out a robot taxi service would take massive investment. You need all kinds of infrastructure to support. So if there was not Waymo then that would probably not be a difficult decision. But there is Waymo. Who has now implemented successfully in three cities and are adding 2 more, Austin and Atlanta. It will be very difficult for Tesla to now compete. It would even be if Tesla was ready to start trials today. But we are now talking years away for them to do the car. There is so much going against the second mover in this space. There is a significant and natural regulatory capture aspect. Whoever comes after Waymo is going to have a very difficult time not getting into hot water with the permit granters. Because you are constantly going to get compared to Waymo who has just run a very clean operation. Anyone new is going to have some trouble and when compared to Waymo they are not going to fare well. Pun intended. The other aspect is that Waymo will have all kinds of loyalty programs already in place. So things like you get the Diamond status level and you go to the front of the line when waiting for cars and you get the better cars.

To me, the real challenges lie in both legal and practical matters. For the sake of argument, lets assume all the grand claims about these automobiles are true. Perhaps they will cost 500 or less by 1926 and can drive further than a horse can walk. Even if that happens, no one has the legal clearance to run cars on the roads. A few companies have permission to test some motor cars, and theyre reporting back decent results. But those are using advanced techniques like trained drivers, etc. The rollout of these cars will depend heavily on new laws and regulations, not just the technology itself. That will take time. Beyond that, these vehicles will need fuel, and sure, there might be some ideas about gas stations, but that still requires infrastructure, and not a single refueling station is built for such a system. Then theres the issue of smog from the cars... This is where I believe the more sensible approach lies with something like the horse and carrage companies we already have, who are working with horsedrawn carriages and have the infrastructure and manpower to operate in most major cities or at least scale to do so. Even if you solve all these problems, youll still be unlocking a lot of pentup demand for transportation. Theres a reason you need a license to operate a hackney carriage in New York Cityif anyone could run one, the streets would be even more gridlocked than they already are. Now imagine every streetcar rider deciding they want to take an automobile instead. You might be better off walking at that rate. And thats just with current horse ridershiptheres always latent demand, which will impact cities. This future will surely require new regulations. The vision is clear, and yes, in the long term, this is how transportation might operate, alongside other methods like railways, and maybe even air travel one day. But for now, they should focus on proving the concept and setting themselves up to scale. Otherwise, they risk disappointing investors with unmet promises.

And then you also have to ponder what would happen with demand, would more people opt for taxis instead of the metro, would there be latent demand of people now walking or shopping online that would suddenly choose to take a taxi? Yes and technically speaking you could swarm them. So in more urban areas or on highways you could have virtual trains. This isnt as efficient as an actual train but close. Youd probably want to put those on dedicated lanes though and the length of such virtual trains is limited by the shortest street on the route. Youd probably also want transfer hubs where local smaller vehicles cheaper to operate could transfer the riders into bigger vehicles which are more efficient in urban areas. These hubs will be massively interesting for real estate developers, riders will still want Starbucks and avocado toast! Just for fun lets look at an example, John lives in a small village about 2 hours away from the major metro area in his region. He hails a car from his home and waits a couple of minutes to arrive while he finishes his first coffee of the day. The taxi picks him up and takes him for a 30 minute ride to the outskirts of the city. There he exits the taxi and goes into the transfer hub, he could directly step onto a virtual train into the city centre, but the coffee he drank is having its effect and he needs a quick stop. He walks to the nearest restroom through the transfer hub where he can see lots of advertisements and walks past a few stores. As he walks back to the platforms he sees a coffeeshop and he decides to go in for lunch, its quite busy because all the office workers in the office building on top of the transfer hub had the same idea. While he finishes his lunch he plots the next leg of his journey and his taxi is already waiting for him on the Platform, he jumps in and the taxi waits for the next virtual train to depart. A few minutes later it does and goes on the highway. While the virtual train continues on further into the city, Johns taxi breaks off and parks him right in front of the building where his daughter lives.

replies.text: Seems like there was a pretty strong majority wanting the 50bp cut. Not particularly divided, just not in perfect agreement. They may have used the weak jobs report as an argument to favour the 50bp cut against those who are more hesitant but I doubt it was the deciding factor. The fact is inflation is pretty spot on where they would hope it would be. They wouldnt want it to be much lower right now, otherwise the risk of overshooting would look to great, with high interest rates still likely pressuring inflation downwards, with the effect lagging. The better than expected jobs report since shouldnt change their course of action as long as inflation continues to come in in line with expectations. The balancing act theyre trying to pull off is working out perfectly for them so far, and pausing cuts due to a healthy economy with inflation in the target range would make very little sense. They would be shooting themselves in the foot. Theyre just as aware of the risk of deflation and recession. Theyre close to pulling off their dream scenario

Powell forcing through a jumbo cut right before a massive jobs beats and hot wages... Market pricing before the leak to WSJ Nick Timiraos was 0 for a 50bp move... Hard to argue this was not a politicized move. Sure it could end up being right. But it is hard to argue the Fed is data dependent when they ignore the data. Edit I wrote before. The responding comment makes no sense.
Rumors have it, the Fed will NOT cut rates!!!
They may have cut rates but I still am not seeingfeeling any relief on my end.

Theres some lunatics in there like Bowman and Bostic that just want to see the world burn. Luckily the median of the Fed board is fairly reasonable. But its not gonna stop the loons from speaking their opinion.
The report cites substantial which doesnt sound like pretty strong majority. It sounds like multiple governors were against a 50bp and were forced to agree to the jumbo cut.
You cant ignore future data, my friend. It hadnt happened yet.
Have you ever thought that feeling the effect of rate cuts take time?
no shot you thought a rate cut would improve your individual life for no apparent reason a month in

9 people wanted 3 cuts total or less in 2024, which means they wouldve favored a 25 bps cut in Sept. Theres really no good reason to start with 50 bps cut, and then not cut at all in 1 out of the next 2 meetings. Cutting by an extra 25 bps 1.5 months early is not gonna make or break the economy, but it creates a huge inconsistent image if you start with 50 bps and then pause the next. Most of the 3 cuts people were probably pressed by Powell to not dissent on the vote. Otherwise, 919 dissents wouldve looked bad, and Trump wouldve shredded the Fed to pieces. 10 people wanted 4 cuts or more total in 2024. The median is more divided than you think.

If they cut too soon inflation will reaccelerate. Probably not immediately but in a year or so. Cutting too soon just makes things worse for everyone in the long run, and promotes economic inefficiency by allowing inefficient businesses access to lower rate loans.
Did you even read my comment? I wrote before.

The data happened before the meeting, hence the 0 pricing of 50bp jumbo cut on Monday before meeting. Powell then leaked his decision to Timiraos at WSJ. I didnt suggest somehow the Fed could know the future data, just that the data they had convinced the market the Fed wouldnt do 50bp jumbo cut. CPI beat, unemployment rate fell, jobless claims fell.
I mean, sure. I just wanted them to take less time Im not even close to a financial expert, I dont understand how these things work. It was an idle comment about my reality.

no shot you thought a rate cut would improve your individual life for no apparent reason a month in LOL. Youre surprised some random person on the internet had a dumb ideahope? But if youre asking for the reason. I was fantasizing about refinancing my home loan the instant JPow published the press release.
The Fed clearly thought that by squeezing in an extra 25 bps 1.5 months early, during the blackout period when they could not communicategive forward guidance to the market.

Theres a very good reason to cut a half point and then pause in one of the next two meetings if you feel you should have cut in July, but are behind the curve. The Fed is constantly adapting to changing data. And all the recent data points to strong economy the recent jobs report was insanely bullish, so I certainly could see them pausing, particularly given their historical hawkishness. Although quarter point is also possible. I think the most likely scenario is two quarter point cuts. As far as where the median lies, I dont understand your math. There arent 19 relevant people in the Fed. Nonvoters opinions dont matter they can talk all they want, but they dont set policy. The 12 votes that matter are here You can somewhat assume the 4 hawkish dots in the June dotplot are likely Bowman, Schmid, Bostic, and Kashkari. Of those, two are voting this year, and two are voting next year. So at best worst?, 2 of the 12 voting members of the Fed are effectively not in favor of cutting much further. Moreover, the 2025 Fed voting picture gets even more dovish since it brings in Goolsbee...youre going to have 4 doves, 2 hawks, and a middle that slides a bit more dovish.
Well... thats actually reasonable, disregard

Theres very little difference between JulySeptDec cut and SeptNovDec cut. Like I said, 25 bps 1.5 months late doesnt mean much on the real economy. Their dot plots were done before the strong data. That means they thought 5.5 was obviously way too high to warrant starting with 50 bps cut, but then 5.0 is somehow not that high to even warrant a cut? When youre talking about Fed medians, Im assuming youre talking about all officials. Among 2024 voters and 9 people who put in 3 cuts in 2024, Bowman, Bostic, Barkin, and Waller wouldve all preferred a 25 bps cut. Hammack was a voter, but no clear side from her yet. I was talking about Sept dot plot, not June dot plot. I dont know why youre bringing up June dot plot to describe voters in Sept. Also, that dovehawk spectrum is pretty wrong by the way. Kashkari has turned back into a dove already and thinks the risk shifts more towards weaker labor market. Barkin is the third most hawkish Fed member behind Schmid. Dalys a dove, and Wallers much more hawkish than Powell, who is now pretty much a dove. In fact, Waller probably sets the tone for where the hawks stand, which was why the Sept vote was very surprising because the Friday before the blackout period, Waller came out and didnt give forward guidance for a 50 bps cut, which caused even the most dovish forecasters like Citi to move to predicting 25bps cut. For 2025, you get Goolsbee but loses Daly. You get Collins which is pretty much centrist, and Hammack is unknown. Loses Bostic but gets Schmid, so its pretty much the same as 2024.

lol, Kashkari changing his view on cuts literally in just the last month or two doesnt make him a dove...hes been plastered on the moar hikes bandwagon practically all year hes on the record as saying rate hikes arent off the table as late as May 28th If anything, the fact hes acquiesced to cuts and significant ones at that is more of a sign of how much sentiment has shifted, even among the hawks. Whereas nothing is perfect, I found that cheat sheet to be relatively accurate. Daly isnt a dove...in fact, Ive seen Daly go back and forth quite a few times in sentiment, very similar to Powell and Williams, both of whom are fairly rated in the middleish. They all tend to be reactive more than proactive. The fact you call Powell a dove is nuts. If he was a dove, they would have cut a quarter point in June when they should have. Hes _very_ clearly more weighted towards overvaluing the inflation side of their dualmandate. Waller may be a _touch_ too dovish on the chart, but marginally...hes nowhere near the Kashkari range. Hes probably somewhere between Barkin and Bostic. At that rate, youre really splitting hairs though. For 2025, I still disagree. Losing Daly, who is close to the middle, is not the same as gaining Goolsbee. When it comes down to it, I kinda view it like the Supreme Court...BowmanBosticSchmidKashkari are your AlitoThomases...you know what theyre going to do before they vote. Kugler, Barr, Goolsbee, and Cook are like Sotomayor...you know what theyre going to do before they vote. Everybody else is somewhere around the Roberts area...their opinions are going to ebb and flow based on prevailing data Daly being in that crosssection. Gaining a Goolsbee and losing a Daly is a distinct dovish shift...its a shift from a situational dove to a definite dove.

Did anyone else on the Fed say the risk is more weighted towards weaker labor market? None. Therefore, Kashkari is NOW a dove. I dont care what he said 12 months ago, because were talking about the present. If you want to talk about the past, why stop at 12 months. Go back 6 years, when he was the most dovish member. If you listened to Daly talk at all, youd see she clearly shifts more towards protecting the labor market. Shes a labor economist by training, and frequently talks about the hardship of lower class workers. Of course shes gonna lean towards protecting the labor market, which hits the lower class the most in recessions. Powell is CLEARLY a dove now. Look at his Jackson Hole speech. He was obviously pressuring the hawks in the committee towards a cut. Whenever Powell speaks at the FOMC or Jackson Hole, he has to represent the whole community, not just his own opinion. The fact that he declared definitively the Fed was cutting when several hawks were still on the fence, and then chimed in his own dovish opinions on a platform where he was representing the whole committee hawks and doves showed he was trying to steer the committee towards him. Even in July FOMC before the weak job report, you could see he was leaning towards a cut when the labor market was supposedly super strong, but couldnt convince the committee to get on board. Hes been itching to cut since July, easily just a notch below Goolsbee, and thats only because he has to represent the whole committee. Barkin is just as hawkish as Kashkari 6 months ago. He rarely talks about inflation progress, and is always cautious that businesses have shifted towards raising price first mindset. He doesnt even want to go back to neutral rate yet, which means he still thinks the risk leans towards higher inflation. In fact, they were frequently among the most hawkish dot plots along with BullardMesterBowman, and BosticWaller 1 notch below them. Waller was always saying the labor market is strong and theres no rush to cut in all his speech. No one knows what Barr will do. Barr doesnt talk about the economy much. He pretty much just follows Powell.

You have a point on Kashkari at the 6 year window. That was a radical change. Although I still dont believe hes currently a dove. Or at least we dont have enough data to show that. Like I said, he was talking a hawkish game literally 4 months ago and has been one of the most hawkish Fed officials for several years running now. I mean hes pretty much a hawkish meme on the internet with his crazy eyes. Is it possible his view radically shifted again? Absolutely. But I dont believe it yet. On Powell, I still disagree. His talk didnt talk dovish until after the June jobs report, when it became club over the head obvious to everyone Kashkari included. Powell talked very hawkish up to the point, including in his response to questions at the FOMC. In general, looking back at the FOMC meets, he would very easily dismiss weakening labor market news and trends and be very quick to latch onto even a subtle shift in inflation numbers. Like inflation would have 1 month of surprise upsurge and he would insist they need 3 more months of good inflation data before they can think of cutting. And if another upsurge happened in those 3 months, hed reset the 3 month counter. That went on nearly all year, fully ignorant of the trendline. And the inverse was true of jobs. Like you would see this clear upward trend in unemployment that he would fully ignore, pointing to the fact it went down in like a single recent report. I could very easily see Powell looking at the recent 254k jobs report, freaking out, and returning to his hawkish talk needing more data, having plenty of time to wait, pausing w tools to respond. Thats his MO...overreact to a single recent event and be slow to react to broader trends. At any rate, agree to disagree on this one, but you have fair points.

You have pretty outdated views. Powell had shifted away from his hawkish stance for almost a year now. He chose to signal a rate cut in Dec 2023 when financial condition was already overpricing Fed cuts, and after financial condition had loosened a lot a month prior. He chose to dismiss the hot inflation prints in Q1 2024 as noise until the third hot print where he basically couldnt dismiss it anymore. He acknowledged that therere seasonal factors that artificially bring up inflation early in the year and bring down inflation later in the year. If this is what he believes in, he should slowly cut until early next year and observe what inflation does, not start with 50 bps cut. Theres also the new president next year which would be inflationary no matter what, so that further adds reasons to go slow and wait until next year. Unemployment rate going up is due to more labor supply, not layoffs. Whats the rush in that? Unemployment was going up for months while we continued to add 250k jobs, and everyone was saying nothing but positive things about the economy. We only shifted down to 150k jobs for 2 months and now suddenly the labor market is weak? Consumer spending is strong, job confidence is strong. If there was any real risk of recession, economists and the market wouldve already flagged that, but none have so far. Btw, a dove focuses more on the job mandate, and a hawk focuses more on the inflation mandate. It doesnt matter what the reason for their focuses are, but Kashkari is now a much bigger dove than the rest when the rest of them saw the same data. Same with Powell.

Ive literally watched every FOMC meeting like a hawk. Shift is not something Id attribute to Powell. If anything, the story of 2024 is that he says the same thing, reiterating himself again and again and again. Hell, the whole reason the stock market would tank after each Fed meeting is because people kept expecting the dovish cuts are coming soon convo and hed stubbornly stick to hawkish dont even think about it, we need more data, promptly causing a rapid sell off in equities. The market was overpricing cuts because they literally were ignoring the words coming out of his mouth. Even as late as the June meeting, it was hawkish words To quote the above link For a seventh straight meeting, the FOMCs statement repeats language stating that the committee doesnt expect to cut rates until it has gained greater confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2. Powell doubled down on the dot plots hawkish tone at the press conference, proclaiming, If the economy remains solid and inflation continues to persist, we are prepared to maintain the current rate level. If the labor market were to weaken significantly...we are prepared to respond Thats literally the exact same stance he was running for 7 meetings prior hold rates steady, wait for data. There wasnt a hint of dovishness there. He doesnt say anything like were preparing to cut soon. That didnt come until Jackson Hole following the dismal June jobs report. On the labor market, it is weak, but macroeconomics dont turn on a dime. Show me any time in history on this chart where the unemployment rate starts turning upward and then stops or declines after only three quarters of a percentage point You wont find it. Sentiment and trends are long term glacierlike snowballing effects. Its why you cant see a recession until youre in it. Because if all youre focusing on is present data whilst ignoring a clearly developing trend, youll never see it. Sure, the labor market is fine now. But thats not what Im concerned about. Do you ever wonder why the Fed is always behind the curve and seems to miss the boat all the time? Always reacting and cleaning up messes after economy implosions instead of being ahead of the ball? This is why. Theyre going to see that most recent 254k jobs report and go look, everything is fine, we can maintain the rate. Then the next month the jobs report is going to be adjusted or abysmal, and once again theyll be behind the curve. Honestly, for entities that constantly claim to care about longterm data, Im shocked at how shortterm thinking they truly are. Inflation has been on a clear downward trend since at least August 2023, and only now they start releasing the screws? When were only a half percent above 2 CPE?

your quote is not a hawkish quote. It is a neutral quote. A hawkish quote would not include the latter part where they are prepared to respond swiftly to deteriorating labor market, which is what Powell did in 2023, not mentioning any concern for the labor market. Please interpret the quote yourself instead of relying on someone else to do it for you. The FOMC statement is crafted by the WHOLE committee, not Powell alone. The dot plot was hawkish in June, but Powell was not. Powell only has control in the FOMC QA. If you think dovish signal can only come from were preparing to cut soon, youre not following the FOMC that closely. Powell can signal dovishness by what he choose to say or not say, what he chooses to emphasize. For example, therere 2 conditions for him to cut rates falling inflation, deterioration of labor market. Only 1 condition for him to HOLD rates, not even hike higher inflation. That right there shows a HUGE dovish bias, and he made this shift late last year. This is evident in the financial condition, which was the tightest late last year and have eased down to summer 2022 levels. Sp500 rallied 300 points after June FOMC. Not sure where the selloffs youre talking about are. The only time the market sold off this year due to hawkish Fed was in April after 3 consecutive bad inflation prints, but not during FOMC. Any instance when unemployment turns upwards and then stop? Summer 2023. Remember when all the recession forecasts became soft landing forecast? Or you already forgot. initial claims also spiked back then too. But why does it matter. Unemployment rate is spiking due to labor supply, not firing. Show me any instance in the past when unemployment rate spiked up due to labor supply.

That quote is only a neutral quote if were at a neutral rate. Powell himself claims the rate we were at prior to the recent half point cut was a significantly restrictive rate, with the rate were at now still restrictive even after the cut. When we get to 2 inflation, we should ideally at that point be at a neutral rate. Because of that reason, the quote is hawkish. Its ignoring the data, ignoring the trend, and preparing forassuming the worst i.e. inflation to reinflate. A neutral stance would have reacted to falling inflation by slowly reducing the rate restriction so that we would be near a neutral rate near the same time we hit 2 inflation. That is not going to happen. Were going to hit 2 CPE within months and wont be anywhere near a neutral rate until sometime in 2026 per even the latest dot plot. Unemployment didnt go anywhere in summer of 2023. That entire time unemployment was in the 3.4 3.8 range and effectively moved sideways. Mainly because we had slack from tons of job openings to absorb any declines in business activity. That buffer has all but evaporated at this point Future weakening in the job market wont come from unfilled openings, itll come from actual filled job positions. As can be seen from the upwardly trending unemployed per job opening chart I also dont know why you seem to believe that the only reason unemployment is trending up is due to supply. There are many sectors in our economy that are laying off people left and right. Tech is one of the big ones Other industries are slow to follow because companies are still afraid to release their workers after the acute shortage they just went through in the proceeding years. So they are choosing to hold workers at a loss rather than release them. At some point those fears will subside. Consumer spending has been declining through all of 2024 and people are becoming increasingly selective about where they spend their money, particularly on big ticket items. Hell, the automobile market all but collapsed people just arent buying cars anymore. Until I see any of these trends break, Im going to assume theyre going to continue. Im seeing a consumer tightening their belt more and more with every passing day, and companies downsizing more and more every passing day.

replies.text: I love Rivian, but they really need to get their shit together. For anyone curious, you can cancel plans for them to be profitable anytime soon. Im still convinced at least one more share offering is coming.

Theres always going to be a lag between how much are made vs delivered. If they only deal in made to order than every single car they produce is sold but some not delivered. Will be interesting to hear more on their earnings call, I imagine theyll go into more detail.

The R1S is a remarkable vehicle. Well above the competition. They really did a nice job designing it and it is a gem to drive. The R2 looks like it will be even better improving some features vs R1. If they can profitably sell it at a lower and profitable price, Rivian should be fine.

But the bigger issue is that the Maverick is about the smallest truck you can buy outside the Hyundai Santa Cruz. I mean, I still like it but for what they are, Rivians are horrible value for the expense.
Noway is Rivian making money this year. If were lucky perhaps last quarter of 25. Its a long term game from here on out.

The Maverick doesnt have a motor on each wheel for offroading, 770 horsepower and autonomous driving software

I like the overall look but once I really started to pay attention, the hood is too long and the bed is too short for being a truck. Its horrible use of space. Its overall size makes no sense relative to its 54 bed. A Maverick is 17 shorter overall, but you somehow get the same bed, more front leg room, more rear headroom, and are only losing like an inch on rear leg room. That is insane considering the T1 costs as much as an F150 Lightning.
Yeah I dont care. Most people dont need that.
Would take the Lightning all day

Watching media in a VR headset is a really cool experience, but apps like Netflix either arent good or arent available in the headset, so you often have to use the browser for them. Thats another case where having a high powered PC makes the headset better because you can just mirror your computer screen. Theres exercise and productivity uses for it, but I dont have much experience with that. Some people love it, but both those cases work better if you can see your environment. Unfortunately the passthrough is just not quite there yet to make it usable for long periods of time for me personally. Thats why Meta is making glasses so you dont need passthrough. Even though theres benefits, its hard to convince people to do their entertainment, exercise, and productivity inside of VRAR when the drawbacks are so apparent. Again, I love my Quest 3 though and recommend it to people, but theres a ways to go before it will get widespread adoption. Itll get there, Meta is doing a great job imo in innovating in this space.

Theres a lot of reason to think that. Take your first example, traffic directions. They have to figure out exactly where youre looking and seamlessly embed the directions into it to make it not drive you insane. If its just the same map as the phone but overlaid, youre creating a blind spot. If there is even the slightest lag where the arrow drags, its going to make you crazy and cause problems. Thats before we even begin to talk about the liability of something impeding vision while driving. Having played significantly with OCR Optical character recognition trying to apply it for a project at work, I have no faith at all it could translate the text on random signs into another language. It likely wont even get the original language right. The AR art displays is an interesting idea though. I could also see it being used as an enhancement for Pokemon GO style games. The other thing you have to think about is that a lot of this processing would need to be done locally by the glasses. If it requires too much processing and has to be sent to the cloud and back, the lag is going to mess with you pretty bad. I think youre on the right track for use cases, but I think your ideas are way ahead of where the technology actually is.

The union asking for pensions instead of 401k contributions is stupid for many reasons 1. With pensions, youre stuck at your job even if you dont like it because you dont want to lose unvested benefits, whereas with a 401k, you generally vest much faster, so they are much more portable. Worse yet, you can get laid off and lose your pension. 2. 401ks are much more flexible because you can access your money when you need it. 3. Pensions are not immune from risk to the employee, because they can fail and be cut if the company underfunds them and goes bankrupt. Its not some magic guaranteed income stream. 4. If you want a fixed income safe from market risk, there are annuity products you can purchase using your 401k funds that provide a lifetime income stream the same way that a pension does.

Because as long as the company doesnt go under, the pension is far more valuable in the long run. My government funded pension allows me to collect 85 of my highest salary for life after 30 years of service.

Because 401ks require much higher contributions for an equivalent payout about twice as much actually. Defined benefit pensions are a much better deal from a financial perspective. Theres a number of reasons for this. 401ks have higher management fees, for one. For another, workers with a 401k must save enough and withdraw at a low enough rate to stretch their savings until they die, whereas pension funds only need to save enough for the average workers lifespan. Finally, pension funds can have an optimal asset allocation at all times, whereas individual accounts must be shifted from highreturn stocks to lowreturn bonds to avoid the risk of a market crash. Thus, you have a high rate of return when you are young and have virtually no money in the account, and a low rate of return when you are old and you have a lot of money in the account, which cuts the potential returns massively.
Thats basically it. You quit a job and cash it out and pay penalties and buy a boat. And Im fine with that. Its just those people will be the first screaming at 62 when they are broke.

They were a very good deal compared to 401k. Companies would pay out pensions for decades far in excess of even the best case return scenario in a 401k. They were devised at a time when lifespan was shorter and often as a way to delay opex to free up cash for debt and investment. Problem is their deals had to be good for employees to accept such a bargain, and when the bills came due when employees began retiring, companies started going bankrupt. It was an unsustainable system made worse by the short term thinking of both employers and employees.

My employer puts in 10k a year to my retirement account. Not out of my paycheck, just extra. If I contribute for 10 years then leave this employer, and it earned a 8 inflation adjusted returnSP500 average over the next 30 years, Id have 1.5 Million in retirement. That would be enough to basically cover more than half my income. In comparison, at a previous job that did have a pension, if I work there less than 10 years, I get nothing. If I work there 10 years and then leave, I get like 20 of my ending salary... which would just get eroded by inflation over the next 30 years before I reach retirement age, so it would only cover like 5 of my living expenses. Pensions are not a magic free lunch. What matters is how much money an employer contributes to a plan, not whether its a 401k or pension.

In Arizona, we will comply with local regulations and pursue similar industry design standards for water management. Two important aspects of our approach are water recycling and water reclamation At startup, approximately 65 of the water used in the Arizona operation will come from TSMCs inhouse water recycling systems. The recycled water will be used in systems such as our air scrubbers and cooling tower systems. To achieve our goal of 90 water reclamation, We will build an advanced water treatment facility Industrial Water Reclamation Plant at our Phoenix operation with a design goal of achieving Near Zero Liquid Discharge. This means the fabs will be capable of using nearly every drop of water back into the facility. replies.text: SPAXX is an interest based investment so you can only make money two ways. The first is by investing longer and the second by having a higher rate. I would assume but dont honestly know that the rates from both SPAXX versions would be the same. If that is correct, the earlier your money is invested, the more compounding you will get. If not, it would be a time versus rate comparison but its likely the higher rate would win as you would be paid the higher rate for the whole month versus the time between investments. One way to test would be to put the same amount in each on the same day and see which is higher over time.

The only true way to compare different financial income instruments bonds, CDs, ETFs, mutual funds, etc. is to use the SEC 7day yield or the SEC 30day yield. The SEC recognized that different institutions could calculate a yield differently from others and end up being misleading. Therefore, in order to provide everyone a fair way to evaluate the yield of different income instruments, they created these two calculations. Mutual funds will use the 30day, while most money market funds use the 7day.

Well, youre asking about a money market fund managed by Fidelity. SPAXX is their fund, they directly manage the assets and dividend payouts regardless of where you hold it. They may be able to answer your questions about whether the delay on dividends on SPAXX holdings in your Chase account compound and affect future dividend earnings. For what its worth, my gut feeling is that the way the extra Chase layer between you and Fidelity delays the dividend payments doesnt actually change the total compensation for you. Fidelity knows what money you have in the fund and how things would compound, even if it takes an extra couple days for it to reflect on your end in Chase. But Im not 100 certain about that. Chase may have the answer, idk, but Fidelity definitely would.

So Im going to take this a slightly different direction. Real Mistakes Intel has made 1. Looking into Holographic DUV rather than going all in on EUV. This is what caused them to lose their market position. This was the result of bean counters hoping the cheaper process would be good enough, but while it worked the yield rates were too low causing it to become uneconomically viable and forcing intel to not shrink their chips for multiple generations to maintain economic viability. 2. Some bugoversight causing 13th 14th gen chips to damage themselves slowly with overvoltage issues. They say they have it under control now with the new microcode update. Only time will tell if that is true. Mistakes INVESTORS are worried about that we dont know the outcome of yet 1. Massive investments into new fabs without a clear roadmap, clientele, etc who will use their contracting services. This makes their balance sheet look like shit and if they dont get some big clients this will be a gigantic waste of money. 2. Their mistakes and anticonsumer approaches are degrading a core customer base in the server sector. AMD is also going after the server market more aggressively. This puts their long term market position in jeopardy. 3. They are making a lot of long term bets on things like GPUs that are hemmoraging money. While I believe this is probably best for them in the long term investors want their money this quarter and these types of plays are just not what they want to see. Reasons to be optimistic 1. Their current chips have honestly caught up to AMD. The 14th gen that arent killing themselves match or exceed the top AMD chips in a wide variety of tasks. 7800X3D is overall best gaming GPU but after that there is a long list of great performance cpus from intel. 2. The 9000 series from AMD is overall a bit of a dud. VERY little benefit over the 7000 series which a large part of the 14th gen already was beating. The 7800X3D still best for consumers and while most of the benefits for the 9000 series is for servers and heavey multithreaded workloads the jump isnt particularly impressive and well below what we normally expect for a generational leap. If 15th generation even an average boost compared to 14th gen its VERY likely intel takes a clear lead in the market. My take. Intel is making multiple long term plays and people are getting super ancy because they have had 2 major mistakes in the last decade. These are really risky gambles with hundreds of billions of dollars and if even 1 of these turns out to be a complete failure it will be a huge issue for the company. By end of 2025 first service fabs will be online, battlemage gpus will be out, and we will know if 15th gen is better than 9000 series or if they also stumble like AMD on this generational update. Given the massive hits in their recent stock, there likely is a lot of upside potential IF they pull it off. The idea they are risk adverse to me doesnt really track with their current heavy investment strategy. The culture might be risk adverse but they are playing with fire here. Messing up and having another microcode issue is something they CANT afford. AMDs messups are giving them an opportunity to regain their footing and we wont know how this plays out until probably end of next year. I expect the stock to go down or stay put until we see how these bets pay off and any investment in INTEL is just betting on this stuff working out. Only project that has me super worried for them is the contract fabs. Its REALLY not clear who they would be getting contract work from. Unless they get an Nvidia, Qualcomm, etc style client I honestly DONT know how they can justify the cost and I just dont see any of those companies leaving TSMC in a serious capacity. There just arent many customers in the world that can even use this service and stealing them from TSMC wont be easy.
I feel like Microsoft made a comeback after a similar rut. Perhaps Intel can too. Ive got 3 shares though, so Im probably thinking wishfully.

Myself, my forte is in making services and products undeniably great, and letting quality drive the business side. Not to the exclusion of shrewd business strategy and tactics, but I just put the priority on having something great that people want, and letting that be the flywheel. So for me, Id finally accept the incredibly common perception that Starbucks actual coffee is mediorceburnt. Weve seen others publicly and with humility accept and fix that... see McCafe, DPZ, CMG, etc. For those who say you cant make that change! I say you cant expect big changes unless you make changes. For those who say the old is good enough, I point to the stock performance as proof its not. Id be the best quality and go with a nicer but more broadly appealing taste profile. As SBUX, wed have the scale and resources to get the very best while still benefitting from scale. Im not sweating about margins in the first wave of this transformation because frankly a drink that you can charge a food price for suggests margin not be a problem over time. Second Id embrace some tech. People are kind of over the myth that you need a slow paced barista teasing out your drink for five minutes. CafeLux and Nespresso have shown you can get 90 of great coffee or cold drinks without lifting a finger. Id seek to take the best of learnings from those and apply them to a faster service model. Maybe that means the barista role is to focus on the part only they can do, and do best, but spares them from the other 90. Thats still TBD, but the goal of pumping out the actual drinks, cold or hot, WAY faster is not negotiable. In parallel wed have some kind of highly mediamentionable value choices. Perhaps not the 99 cent coffee that every pundit thinks they were the first to think of, since it would only be reinforcing the oldbad taste and also trading short term traffic surge which isnt the problem for weaker reputation and perception. But maybe some quick and easy 3 buck options that are enough to generate broad public knowledge. The taste and speed have to be newsworthy upgrades. The value options must also generate a buzz, but should be aligned with supporting not undermining the first two priorities. There would be more phases, but the emergency mission would be whole new supply and taste, combined with huge efficiency boost by automating that which can be. That phase alone probably justifies yesterdays 20 billion move.

They are the biggest reinsurer in the world afaik if you need to insure for tens of billions and you want to be guaranteed to be paid if things go south you have very limited options and Berkshire is one that has that kind of money. So, when it comes to their balance sheet, they need to put their potential liabilities as...liabilities. This until they renew the contracts still liabilities, or they expire so they move to the other side of the balance sheet.
Equity Assets Liabilities

The question above was about their cash holdings vs their investments. You cant measure Berkshire solely on the basis of their stock holdings, since it only makes up about 30 of their total assets. Yes, their stock portfolio gets the most media attention, but they wholly own many companies that contribute to their total assets and thus returns. Also, if you want to take into account 1.1 trillion in assets, then you need to also look at liabilities. Out of the 1.1 trillion, over 100 billion are intangibles and another 220 are plant, property, and equipment assets think trains, trucks, and powerplants. Looking at the liabilities of Berkshire, they have 120 billion in long term debt and 222 billion in other liabilities. Looking at Berkshire as a whole, you need to take into account all of these assets and liabilities. Their latest earnings were helped by a company they wholly own GEICO but brought down by their utility assets and BNSF which they also wholly own.

I also know what debt is, but again could they not have x amount total assets, y cash, and xy investments? Why should investments be counted as equitycash instead of assetscash, liabilities arent included in assets.
Cuba is doing better than literally every single one of its neighbors except the us so sure Ill think about it

They can be with companies. They can have loans invested into assets like stocks, buildings, etc. As well as cash invested into assets. Total Assets means the gross values of any assets regardless of if said assets has a loanliability underwriting it

I understand, but again why would you subtract that loan from the value in investments. If buffet had 800 bil in just the stock market, and 500 of that was from borrowed money, hed still have 800 in the market.
But the liability will have to be paid back when you realize the asset for cash! Equity is your net profit from an asset
DUDE EQUITY ASSETS LIABILITIES

I know! But still, hed have 800 billion in the market. If that turned into 1 billion, you wouldnt say he turned 200 into 400, youd say he turned 800 to 1000 and owes 600. If he has more than 200 billion invested, then he has more than 200 invested. It doesnt matter how much he owes.
I heard you the first time but thats not my question. Could you rephrase what you think my question is for me.

He has that on paper but money in real life terms is only as valuable as what you can actually liquidate it for. His Equity would move in line with the investment so its a better indicator into the health of Berkshire. For Example If you have 500M in cash and 1.5 Billion in assets but your liabilities are 2 Billion. Youre worth nothing in real terms but have 1.5 Billion in investments. Not very healthy. If you dont look at this from an Equity and cash ratio view then you can be easily deceived by companies and their financial health.

You are asking how equity, which youre equating to cash in the market, is related to liabilities. The equation is telling you that if you have 100 in your checking account but a 50 phone bill, you only have 50 available to put in the market.

Yeah completely agree, of course having a lot of liabilities is bad. I just meant that the whole original comment thread was talking about his cashinvestment ratio, and its a bit ridiculous to say its almost 11 when its of course not. It being 11 is so much more indicative of buffet thinking a recession is near than his position currently probably is, and thats pretty much what the whole post is discussing. The distinction is pretty important.
No, Im asking how cash in the market is related to liabilities. Read my replies with another reply, he understood what I meant and we both agreed,

JFC dude. If you have bills to pay, you need cash to pay those bills. If all of your cash is in the market, you have to take it out at a gain or loss to pay your bills. Its a dumb as shit way to invest btw. Please tell me now you understand this.

You seem to just not want to understand what Im asking. Thats fine, already came to a conclusion with a person who can think critically. No one is forcing you to type, if you dont feel like putting in the effort into understanding, you dont have to.

Yes. But Gelsinger is really working off of mistakes made by leadership 810 years ago. Foundry leadership in particular is not simply won or lost in a quarter, or even a couple of years. For example, when Intel first released its 14nm CPUs in Q3 2014 TSMC was on a 20nm process and TSMC vs Intel processes are not 11. Eg Intels 10nm is akin to TSMCs 7nm. Intel didnt move away from a 14nm process on desktop consumer chips until Alder Lake in November of 2021. In that time TSMC went from a 20nm process to a 4nm one albeit not in full production. So in 7 years Intel went from leading TSMC by several generations to being behind by between 12 generations. By the time Gelsinger joined in 2021 the most extensive damage had been done. This isnt even going into the design side Intel missed mobile, GPUs, ARM, etc. They were slow to adopt chiplets, have confusing NUMA configs due to P and E cores vs AMD, and they arent where AMD is with 3D caches. They are in the DPU game with their IPUs but their only customer is Google, AWS is ahead with Nitros and Azure has their own play with Azure Boost. replies.text: Roll all old 401ks into 1 IRA Rollover account not another 401k Youll then have the benefit of being able to invest in anything you want, as opposed to the limited 401k options provided by an employer plan. Theres no downside to this

If you have a 401k at your current employer, you can roll the other 401ks into that, but youd want tot make sure there are good investment options there with low fees. You cant open a 401k yourself since your employer needs to do that. You could also roll them into a Rollover IRA at Schwab. That will give you access to much better investment options, however it will also complicate things if you want to do a Backdoor Roth IRA conversion in the future. You should probably also consolidate both of your brokerage accounts into one, unless you have a reason to keep them separate. You shouldnt need to sell off the stocks which would mean you need to pay capital gains tax to do that.

I dont currently have an employer, and have not most of the year. As a result, this would actually also be a great year to sell of some stocks edit from my brokerage account and independent of any 401k and eat away at the tax liabilities while my income is much lower than average years. That also means I dont have a current 401k contributor. Perhaps it would benefit me to hold off until I do, and at that point I could move both of the old 401k into that one. Assuming it is a good low fee option of course.

Given your circumstances, one option is to rollover the 401ks into a traditional IRA, then do a Roth conversion now. Youd have to crunch the numbers to get a better picture, but that would free you up for backdooor Roths later assuming Congress doesnt kill the option at some point.

A 401k is a tax advantaged account there is no growing tax liability, but if you take money out prior to retirement age there are penalties. Youre thinking of a taxable brokerage account and capital gains tax. In a traditional 401k, you deferred income tax when you made the contribution, so you owe income tax when you withdraw it, but its a percentage of the total so the liability doesnt grow. All that matters is your taxable income the year its withdrawn because thats what determines your income tax rate.
Sorry I was unclear, I did mean liquidating some of my mutual funds and reinvesting as to undo future taxes

Within the 401k? There are no capital gains tax in a 401k, or any kind of tax advantaged retirement account. Theres no increased burden from gains and theres no benefit to realizing gains and bringing up your cost basis.
No outside of it. Simply my brokerage accounts.

replies.text: high yeild is going to normally have lower credit quality bonds so that is why you are getting higher yields. Something like HYG , has only BB and below. JNK is roughly the same. SGOVUSFRTFLO are all Treasury notesbills I would feel much more comfortable with them if memory is correct they are all AA and above, they are all state tax exempt. Also what are these bonds supposed to be used for efund, cash holdings, goal for something else , etc?

BSV is the best candidate I could find for a taxable account. Hold it for its stated duration 2.6 years in order to experience a total return close to its stated YieldtoMaturity 4.10, of which 3.10 will arrive as a taxable dividend, and the remaining 1 will show up in BSVs price, for a capital gain. Basically, with BSV youre locking in todays yield for about 2.5 years. But, Bonus! Because of a peculiarity of the way bonds get repriced based upon their duration, with BSVs 2.6 year duration, expect BSVs price to go up by about 2.60 for each 1 that rates go down, as a rule of thumb.
Generally just for bridging the gap between my emergency fund and long term investments, as an midterm investment, with an overall lower volatility than stocksindex funds.

I personally like to use treasury bonds etffunds due to least correlation to stocks, there a bunch of different options telling on the duration you want schovgsh for short term 13 years roughly, med term VGIT is a good option, for longer durations VGLT, and TLTEDV for longest durations. There is also GOVT, thats kind of like Total bond market for just treasuries. I am not biggest fan of high yield because correlations is bordering close to stocks etfs imo.

Thats a decision to be made based on their fund availability. If you feel your current 401k has better options, then sure, roll it over. If it doesnt, then leave it where it is. Dont forget you have the option to roll over your old 401ks to an IRA as well, which gives you a lot more freedom depending on the firm its at.

What kind of funds are in your older accounts? If you have pre tax funds, I would roll all of that into your current 401k. Roth funds can go into a Roth IRA. Dont underestimate the convenience of having fewer accounts to keep track of.

Ideally roll them all into a single 401k at the same institution. Ideally you also keep your IRAs, HSA, and private brokerage accounts there too, so you have your accounts in a single place. There could be some exceptions, mostly related to the expense fees on your 401ks. If one of your legacy 401ks happens to have a much lower set of fees, then you could consider just keeping it. I have done this because I worked previously at a very large company, and their 401k has significantly lower fees than what my current employer offers. But I cannot roll new money into it as I no longer work there. Thankfully both 401k are held in the same institution. Were that to changed I might consolidate and eat the fees.

I was in a similar situation with many accounts in many companies. I kept one of the 401k as is because that plan offered mutual fund options that are not available outside of that plan with ultra low fees. But finally I deiced to consolidate all my individual, IRA and 401k accounts under one platform because easier management moving forward now that Im close to retirement. Hope this helps.

Brokerage options involve fees that often an ira at a brokerage firm does not usually incur. Ymmv

So, convert in the old 401k plan, then roll to an ira. Paying old company 401k fees is dumb. Otherwise, every year you preserve the backdoor, youre increasing your conversion tax. In which case, fk it, just keep it traditional... Which many argue is the better strategy anyway
No you arent taxed if you move it to a Traditional IRA

Someone correct me if Im wrong, but I believe that if you do a direct rollover, rather than indirect then you should avoid any taxes or penalties as the money goes straight from one institution to the other, rather than via your own bank account.
You have to roll it into a traditional IRA instead of a Roth. Roth is posttax money, traditional is pretax.

At Fidelity, mine is called a Rollover IRA. All my 401k403bs and pensions from previous employers have been rolled into this account. But you must be careful how you do it. Ideally, the payout check needs to be made out to Fidelity FBO, your name and have your account number on it...or something like that. I love having all my money in one account and can invest in whatever I want. Fidelity lets you purchase fractional shares too and I incur no fees to trade in that account. Hope this helps.
Pretax 401k to traditional ira. Roth 401k to roth ira. You you want to convert from traditional pre tax 401k, convert in the 401k to roth 401k, then roll out to Iras of like kind.

No. Converting pre tax to Roth in prime earning years is not usually a good idea. Rolling pre tax funds from former employer 401ks to a current employer 401k plan, rather than into an IRA, usually minimizes fees and preserves the ability to do future backdoor Roth IRA contributions tax efficiently.

Traditional can be pre tax or post tax. Roth is always post tax.

Naw. Modern accounting at the plans and at the firms holding the Iras can preserve the cost basis making conversions available at any time. Because even an in plan conversion creates the tax due. And, 401k plans notoriously have higher fees than a no fee ira invested in etfs... Not always the case, of course, but since companies stopped charging annual ira fund fees, this is often the case. Typical 401k plans have about 25bps of admin fees, according to vanguard how America saves and other studies But ymmv

Thats correct, direct rollovers dont trigger taxes. Ideally get the firm whos getting the rollover to initiate the transaction to pull it from the plan or prior account. Sometimes a retirement plan still wants to send you the check, but then theyll write fbo you the participant, for rollover IRA, custodian Fidelity... Or whomever youre using.

You completely missed my point. There are Traditional pre tax, Traditional post tax, and Roth always post tax types of contributions. All three of these types of funds can be contributed to IRAs, and 401ks depending on the plan.

replies.text: DR has some good advice about budgeting debt in the 1st few baby steps. Some of his investing advice is good, but some is terrible. A novice cant tell the difference. has some great free resources to learn about investing. After a few hours reading the articles, and, especially, watching the Bogleheads Philosophy videos, most beginners can learn how to get better results than most professionals. Bogleheads is named after John Bogle, founder of Vanguard.
You dont need an advisor to do this.
If having an advisor is the only way youd feel comfortable investing, keep him. If not, run as far away as you can.

Mutual funds are a type of security. ETFs are another type of security. They can have lots of things in them. An index fund can be an ETF or mutual fund and it can track any number of different indexes. You can buy ETFs or mutual funds in your 401k, IRA, brokerage, etc. Im not clear on what youre asking specifically.

Are you using an advisor currently? Who is picking your funds for you now? Using your 401K and mutual funds can be great. But this tells us nothing about what the actual asset mix is stocksbondsinternational or what the fees of the funds are or any advisor fees. Im not sure what you mean by investing the Dave Ramsey way. So asset allocation matters a lot. You can be broadly diversified by owning only 34 mutual funds or index funds. And you can be not diversified by owning 20 different funds that have a lot of overlap. Also fees make a huge difference. Not all SP500 funds are the same. Some charge a front load fee of over 5 just to buy the fund. Some funds have a high ER expense ratio of over 1 that you may be paying every year, compared to VOO with an ER of only 0.03. Knowing what you are paying in total fees makes a huge impact. Bogleheads table showing how much fees decrease your nest egg. Paying 1 in fees over 40 years slashes your potential retirement nest egg by 33! A 2 fee loses you 55

I highly recommend picking up the most updated edition of A Random Walk Down Wallstreet. Its a highly informative guide on low cost passive investing and why this is the best strategy for most people. The Bogglehead community also has a lot of good info on how to get started in this approach to investing. Its great that you are saving at all. That puts you way ahead. Even better that you are thinking beyond DR and his advice. Take an empirical approach and follow the facts not personalities. You could do worse than following DRs advice but you can also do a lot better. Good luck and congrats on having six figures saved in your early thirties!

My wife and I were in a similar boat as you When we were young we started with a Financial Advisor and he got us into American Funds funds which I presume is what your stuff is in. The high sales load, as well as I believe thats what Daves network of advisors push, make me presume thats what youre in. When I realized how expensive they were and we had a bad experience with the FA so we fired him I moved everything to Fidelity and started doing it myself. I didnt immediately go into the low cost index fund style of investing. I wish Id done that sooner. I didnt immediately sell all the AF funds wed aleady bought. As I recall I did it over time just to get rid of them. Not sure that was the smartest decision also not sure it was the dumbest. But in the long run am VERY glad we got out of them. Holy smokes theyre expensive AND complicated.
Low expense ratio mutual funds are fine in retirement accounts as you dont have to worry about the tax inefficiencies compared to etfs but in a taxable brokerage, please use ETFs
I did the Dave Ramsey thing to get out of debt. After saving a few hundred thousand dollars...I met with some advisors. In the end , buying SP500 was my choice, I didnt hire a professional.

To start, I dont think you are using a financial advisor, if you are paying a 5 front end load, you are probably working with a mutual fund or insurance sales person. Next, you can get good quality financial advisory services by using Schawb, ETRADE, Morgan Stanley, Fidelity and a whole lot more without paying a front end load on every dollar you invest. Next, if you understand mutual funds the you understand ETFs. A mutual fund is a pool of money that the fund manager uses to buy a basket of stocks with certain objectives in mind and thats the same thing that an ETF is. They differ in how you buy and sell them. Mutual funds are purchased and redeemed through the company that sponsors them and ETFs are traded like stocks. I would really encourage you to reach out to Schawb, ETRADE, Morgan Stanley, Fidelity or other provider that are not commissioned mutual fund or insurance sales people.

People see Dave Ramsey and might not see much else. Dave is not really an investment guy but you can get rich doing his stuff in lockstep. Yes you would end up ahead if an advisor overperformed the market enough to cover their fee. The challenge is most advisors by far dont overperform the market. The stat most commonly cited is something like 85 of professional money managers underperform the market. What Ive learned is that that really means 85 of mutual fund managers underperform the market. So then the question becomes what percent of retail financial advisors underperform the market. I, personally, think its reasonable to extract from the mutual fund numbers to say 85 of Financial Advisors underperform the market.....because if someone was so good at outperforming the market, dont you think one of the big mutual fund companies would hire them to manage their fund? Im confident a mutual fund manager makes a TON more money than a Financial Advisor does.

The Vanguard White Paper does not refute the math that a 1 or 2 fee, all things being equal will decrease your returns. The math table doesnt care if the fee is because you are paying a financial advisor, or if you are paying a high ERfund fee. What the point of the Vanguard paper says in a nutshell is that the average individual investor may do better using a financial advisor by 3 per year. But a full 2 of that performance is by modifying behavioral mistakes that an individual investor may make such as panic selling during the normal market downturns, or performance chasing by constantly switching from one high performing fund to another, or FOMO etc. I do agree with Vanguard that if you dont know what you are doing, or are uncomfortable with the volatility of the stock market or your own emotional responses, then having an FA will likely give you better returns than you can get on your own. But for a savvy DIY investor who has a solid Investment Policy Statement that they will stick to, and knows what mistakes NOT to make, adding a financial advisor will not increase your portfolio performance by 3.
Again dont be obsessed with personalities to the point of caring if their name is misspelled in a reddit comment. Focus on the validity of the investing principles. Dont be like this bot.

There have been a lot of good resources mentioned here plus sites like Fidelity, ETRADE and the rest that can help you learn to take over your investments. If you are not comfortable totally taking them over, companies like the ones I mentioned have very low cost advisory services. Additionally, these companies can help you move your current assets to a different advisor where you will have a much wider variety of investments. EDIT Your current guy will put up resistance as you take over your accounts.

A great way to learn to manage your money is to setup a brokerage account with Schwab, fidelity, etc and buy and sell a handful of stocks and etfs. Once you get a feel for the process its basically the same in a 401k or IRA. The only difference is a 401k tax advantage retirement account and the 401k is probably going to be far more limited in what you can buy, many are usually just mutual funds that are just like etfs, except an etf you can buy and sell at any time throughout the day like a stock, where a mutual fund you sell and it sells after trading is over for the day. An IRA is tax advantaged too but will have all the options of a brokerage account. Mutual funds are set and forget, dividends get reinvested, etc, etfs give you a little more control but can be setup the same way. I find etfs yo be easier because I know what they contain. VOO for example is basically trading the SP500. VFIAX is the fidelity mutual fund version of the same thing. For me mutuals fund are more work because it difficult to find what is in the fund and what proportions. ETF I find are easier because I can buy VOO and buy a few individual share of google or nvidia or something else if I want to be heavier somewhere. There are etfs for almost any specific sector too like healthcare industry, or consumer goods McDonalds coke, etc. There is no wrong way but after a lot of time, many of us have realized that its really hard to do better than just buying VOO. Its really that simple and any advisor worth their salt will put you heavy in the SP500. But seriously just open an account and play around, get comfortable with it and then drop your advisor and manage it yourself and keep that money for your future. Also remember. This is investing, its long term. Dont get in the habit of day trading but I suggest do buy and sell early to get a feel for it.

Its always a good idea to get a second opinion. Unless someone is a fiduciary they are not legally obligated to look out for you. It doesnt mean that youre not in good hands. Having a 2nd option never hurts right..
