At a high level Vanguards research my reading of it compares returns with using an advisor vs the investor doing nothing or if more than nothing pursuing investing in a totally amateurish way. Look at the services breakdown in Figure 1 of the report. Virtually ALL of those can easily be done by an amateur i.e. on their own if theyre willing to put in the relatively small amount of time to actually do them. None of the tasks in that list are difficult or complicated. Using an advisor is WAY WAY better than not managing the investments at all. That doesnt mean a person who does pursue it themselves, and is willing to put some time into and learn about it.....like a hobby, is going to do WORSE than an advisor.

Say you decide to use Schwab, call or visit their local office with the most recent statements from your accounts and tell them you want to find out about their services. They will arrange a meeting with a rep and the rep will take it from there. Im guessing you have Schwab, Morgan Stanley, Fidelity and several other of the big names. Most retirement and 529 accounts are pretty cut and dried. they will charge a small annual fee, gather some information about age, investor temperament, income and those sorts of things and then make some recommendations about which invests are likely to work best for you. Since you are paying an annual fee based on your total portfolio, they will avoid commissioned product because they are not in your best interests. As far as making the switch from the old guy, they will help you do that. I woulkd check out at least 3, inquire about fees and services and pick the one you like best.

replies.text: I mean this is a common criticisms of stock buy backs In general a company does well, it makes a ton of cash then the question is what to do with the cash and well one answer is return it to the owners Well at the same time because the company is doing well and making a ton of cash the market has pushed it stock price up because well its a good company making a ton of cash So yea a common criticism of buy backs is they happen when the stock price is high because that usually is also when the company is making a ton of cash and has free cash flow to return it to investors I guess a potential alternative is just to declare special dividends and return the cash via a special dividend but that also comes with taxes for the owners

Im not a big fan of buybacks or dividends in a company that is still growing quickly, Id rather see cash reinvested into the business. 50B sounds like a lot, but this is a company worth 3T. 50B is roughly 1.6 of float, not exactly a big impact. This company is being priced at insanely high growth expectations, use the cash to meet and exceed those expectations, not to bolster short term share value
IMO they would be better off using the cash to acquire companies than repurchasing their own shares at inflated valuations.

I dont have a problem with that because they have built the company from the ground up. The hyper growth is over but I believe NVDA can still outperform the 500 for a few years.

common criticism of buy backs is they happen when the stock price is high Which is a bit of a silly argument, because if the stock price reflects the value of the company ie if the efficient markets hypothesis is valid then the overpayment is really just a direct transfer of the cash component of the valuation to shareholders. Any shareholder complaining that a buyback is happening at recent highs is tacitly admitting they should have sold their position yesterday.

replies.text: Total yearly cost of attendance ranges for three typical college categories are Instate public 2035k Outofstate public 4060k Private 5090k Middle of the road, thats 200k for a 4 year undergraduate degree in present day dollars. Plug that into an inflation calculator with the rate of your choice, and theres your estimate.

Starting a 529 early is a smart move for sure, and youre right about the compound growth.... it can really add up. for 2047, that 400,000 estimate might not be off the mark considering how tuition has skyrocketed, but predicting exact costs that far out is tricky. Another approach might be to aim for covering 5060 of that estimate and then adjust as you get closer and have a clearer picture of tuition trends and your kids interests.... maybe theyll choose a less expensive school or get scholarships. Also dont forget to check out different states 529 plans because some might offer better benefits or lower fees than your home state, which can also impact your savings growth. Keep an eye on how the plan performs and adjust your contributions as needed.
I am personally aiming for 100k assuming 25k instate tuition and to cover some of the other costs using a typical tax brokerage account. Its very subjective how much you want to put in.
The way I plan to is to look at my states prepaid tuition rate per credit and save the equivalent amount for a bachelors in a 529.
its not as bad as it seems, since the high rates are driven by the rich paying the full ticket prices, if you have in 25 years call it 200300k saved youll be just fine.

For my child I have calculated 50k per year for room and board at public California university when he starts college in a few years. I use 5 percent inflation as a guide. I calculated this over 10 years ago. So I contribute to 529 based on that using a compound interest calculator. I been doing 600 a month for over a decade. The assumption is 7 percent avg return per year. The account is projected to have college fully paid for in a few years.

I started late My first kid was 7 when I learn about 529...started 200 a week trying to catch up. Though I have 3 kids... for to start one for my second kid soon. 3rd kid is in preschool... thats causing 1000 a month. So when she goes to kindergarten, I will start her 529 as well. Lots of money.

Not sure if I can give you a number to shoot for, but saving something is better than nothing. We set up a monthly contribution and just let it ride. Be aware there is quite a bit of flexibility on the use of 529 funds to fund K12 expenses if you want to and transfer between sibling accounts without penalties. So you dont have to be overly careful about parsing between accounts I kinda treat them like one big account even though they are in my 3 kids names. So getting the tax advantages of growth in the 529 can be broadly beneficial for more than just college tuition or room and board. Covers computer costs etc so all these costs will rack up. Might as well park what you can there.

One kid graduated, one is a senior. It was basically 250month each from the day they were born until they graduated. It added up to about 100k each. I think it could have been more, but our 529 had limited investment options on the conservative side. The kids both went to state schools and got off campus housing after freshman year as the dorms cost more than tuition and rent was cheaper with a bunch of roommates. Both kids graduated or will soon graduate with no debt. I dont imagine that state schools will cost 25kyear 20 years from now so I think I would be looking at more like 500month if I did it now. If you want to do a private school I think itll be a lot more unfortunately, but we didnt go that route so I dont have any specific advice for that.

Were SUPER conservative and used the most expensive private school 90K in todays money as a guide. Were looking to cover 600700K over 4 years. So we decided to super fund put 5 years worth of 529 contribution under the 17,000 gift tax limit in at once. replies.text: A solo 401k plan is a 1 participant plan. So by definition its a traditional 401k plan covering a business owner with no employees, or that person and his or her spouse. See IRS definition here Are you maybe thinking about something else if you want to offer a tax advantaged to your employees. What about a SEP or SIMPLE?

An Scorporation can sponsor a Solo 401k plan as long as the Scorp has no fulltime W2 employees other than the owners. The IRS clearly recognizes that an Scorp can have a Solo 401k, also known as an Individual 401k. The Solo 401k can provide benefits to a business owner and their spouse, so long as the spouse is actively employed by the business. In order to sponsor the simplified Solo 401k, however, there can be no nonowner employees of the business that work more than 1,000 hours per year about 20 hours per week. Your business can employee parttime workers, so long as no one employee exceeds a 1,000 hours of service per year threshold. Starting in 2021, parttime employees working at least 500 hours per year in 3 consecutive years will qualify for plan participation. The first year this will really have an impact on Solo 401k eligibility will be 2024. I have provided the above not to refute what you said above. You are correct, those are the parameters that the IRS defines on their website. However, looking further into the details, there are loopholes for certain situations, albeit confusing. I was just wondering if it is possible in my situation and if my employees would also be able to contribute. I am starting to think that is a no.

If you dont want to use a SEP or SIMPLE try talking with some of the 401k providers out there. There could be new options with the passage of SECURE Act 2.0. When I looked into it a few years for my own business my own experience was that a solo 401k was not an option. But my business doesnt elect Scorp treatment. So maybe you have more options.
Great advice thank you

I never really thought about it in terms of the greeks. I just did some backtesting and found that ATM or very slightly OTM leaps were best for average return. To use QQQ right now as an example the 550 12026 calls with 15 to break even were the type of options I started off with. I went into a bit of detail on some of these in my reply to jwp_93 but to summarize I buy around 5 above the ATM price. Option pricing is the main reason I went for XLP. Like, a QQQ leap is the price of 11 shares but an XLP leap is only the cost of 7 shares which could theoretically make up for XLPs lackluster performance. If you meant on a time basis like stocks just went down 30 so volatility is high and options are more expensive I dont take that into account because I dont try to time the market. Never really thought about the greeks, just saw in backtesting that slightly OTM leaps performed better I wont be switching to TQQQ. I wish I could say it was for mathoptimization reasons but I have the if it aint broke dont fix it attitude at this point. I spent a long time forming this strategy 6 years ago and the thought of digging out my old backtesting scripts and updating them with the last few years of data and testing a new leveraged stock strategy against my options strategy to see if maybe its a little better doesnt sound appealing.
Slightly OTM, like 5 above the current ATM price
You could buy leveraged ETF shares or get calls on a highly correlated etf that has a lower share price. Needing 6k to buy even a single ATM leap is a bit crazy for QQQ.

I buy slightly OTM like 5 above ATM price and I got over my fear about buying at ATH by looking at some back testing. As it turns out all time highs are often followed by more all time highs. Obviously the crashes are very attention grabbing so we remember them but on a long term basis the returns have historically outweighed the risks.
Id be hesitant to follow this strategy long term. 2003 saw a crash in both sectors used in your strategy. If it were to happen again, youd be down 7590.

Summary V.F. Corp has experienced fluctuations in its financial performance over the past four fiscal years, showing growth in revenue but facing challenges with declining net income. The companys EBITDA and operating income have varied significantly, while balance sheet metrics have seen declines. Margins and ratios have been mixed, with a notable drop in net profit margin. VFC has faced both positive and negative news in the market and is exposed to diverse risks across operational, regulatory, macroeconomic, competitive, technological, and ESG factors. Key Financial Insights Revenue increased from 9.24 billion in 2020 to 11.61 billion in 2023 but declined to 10.45 billion in 2024. Net income dropped significantly from positive figures to a loss of 968.88 million in 2024. Gross profit margins remained stable, ranging from 41 to 52. Positive free cash flow in most years, except for 2023. Historical volatility of 58 indicates moderate stock price volatility compared to the market. Risk Factors Operational risks from supply chain disruptions and quality control issues. Regulatory risks related to trade policies, labor regulations, and environmental standards. Macroeconomic risks including economic downturns, currency fluctuations, and inflation. Competitive risks due to industry competition and evolving consumer preferences. Technological risks from cybersecurity threats and the need for digital investments. ESG risks impacting brand reputation and consumer perception. Conclusion Given the mixed financial performance, market sentiments, and diverse risks facing V.F. Corp, it is recommended to hold the stock for now. Investors should closely monitor future earnings reports, risk management strategies, and industry trends before making any significant buying or selling decisions.

I was a scientist in the nuclear industry in the 80s and 90s, its going to be a decade before I retire. Ive worked on reactors, reprocessing and warhead production. In the UK. Large reactors can use natural unenriched uranium and are easier to defuel, for Pu239 production. Now. The UK, US and France have too much weapons grade plutonium if anything, so large, difficult to decommission reactors are unnecessary. Theyre massive capital projects SMRs require enriched uranium, but theyre just built in a factory, moved to site, then theyre defuelled and buried when were done with them. Theyre very similar to the submarine reactors that Rolls Royce and Westinghouse Brookfield corp have been making for 60 years. There are also a bunch of startups with high hopes but no engineering experience. My bet is on Rolls Royce. Its a car company that diversified into jet engines and reactors unlike Tesla, which is a car company trying to diversify into novelties and toys. Im also invested in USbased Brookfield because its a great company like an infrastructurefocussed Berkshire Hathaway. Both have been doing very well recently for their shareholders. Small enriched uranium SMRs cant be used to make atom bombs, so they can be made on a production line and sold anywhere without nuclear proliferation concerns. But the 530 enriched fuel has to be purchased from the US, UK, France, China or Russia the nuclear gulf states. Uranium isnt the critical bottleneck you all think it is. The value is added by gas centrifuging UF6. Only governments can do that.

The DD is indeed bending reality. In addition to Vogtle 34, there was another project that survived the postFukushima wipeout of US new nuclear builds. That was V C Summer 23, another pair of AP1000s. Westinghouse was so far behind schedule and over budget in building these four plants that it went bankrupt. Thats why a private equity firm like Brookfield owns them in the first place before it sold half to Comeco. The V C Summer utility decided not to continue, but the Vogtle utility did, at great cost. Its because of this experience and the fact that wind and especially solar are far cheaper these days that no one is looking to build more AP1000s, or any other large nuclear reactors, in the US. Europe has had similar experiences in France, Finland, and the UK. Among nonauthoritarian countries in the last couple of decades, only South Korea has managed to build large nuclear reactors on a reasonable budget and schedule. Id be very wary of all the hype around nuclear, be it uranium, SMRs, or large reactors.

I think we can safely classify China as authoritarian. The UAE too. Haiyang and Sanmen are AP1000s, which, fwiw, is a really great design with excellent safety features. But yes, theyre building a bunch of clones on their own because Westinghouse gave them the IP.

Oh, the AP1000 is a great design, as youll see downthread on the other reply to my comment. Definitely the best LWR design currently on the market. But the nuclear industry always claims that theyll learn their lessons and the next build will be smoother and on time and budget. And it never is. Basically every plant built in the 70s and 80s in the US had huge overruns, and many were cancelled after TMI. Even Watts Bar took much longer to complete than expected. Flamanville in France and Olkiluoto in Finland were similar. Frances original build out in the 70s was similarly over. Taiwan ended up cancelling the ABWRs in Longmen, and that was after a dozen or so were built in Japan. Unless youre an authoritarian country, or maybe South Korea, youre very likely to take far more money and time to build every large nuclear reactor. This time wont be different. This is unfortunately why the nuclear industry, which should be a perfect complement to solar and wind, and perfect for AI, is instead a sunset industry.

The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month.

Update 2 This information is huge regarding final SFAR FAA Rule The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month. I think youll see it is quite responsive to industry comments, Coes told attendees. It will come well ahead of certifications that the FAA is working very hard with our manufacturers. The SFAR was a hot topic at last years summit, where the draft version faced considerable criticism. Industry concerns focused on the certification process for pilots, the requirement for dual flight controls, energy reserves for electric aircraft, and flight simulation training devices. Many in the industry felt the rules governing pilot certification and operations of a novel technology like poweredlift eVTOLs should be modernized to reflect the unique aspects of electrification and range. However, at this years summit, the mood had shifted toward cautious optimism for the release of the final SFAR. Theres great anticipation for the rule, which were told is coming in just a few weeks, said Kristie Greco Johnson, senior vice president of government affairs with the National Business Aviation Association NBAA. If the FAA can deliver the rule in just a few short weeks, itll be a major accomplishment for the agency. While Coes contends the final SFAR will be released in the next month, the FAA technically has until Dec. 16 to finalize the regulation, according to the FAA reauthorizaton bill. The same bill also mandated that a notice of proposed rulemaking NPRM for unmanned aerial systems UAS operating beyond visual line of sight BVLOS be issued by Sept. 16. However, the FAA missed that deadline, raising concerns about the SFARs timely release. There is broad consensus that the U.S. faces stiff competition from global players to lead in AAM. With first movers like Joby Aviation and Archer Aviation aiming for a 2025 commercialization of eVTOLs, the pressure is on the FAA to meet expectations.

How the hell does their eVTOL have have fewer failure points? They have more motors and more propellers not to mention the hinges that have to move to allow them to transition from vertical to horizontal flight. These thing arent exactly maintenance free, they still have to be inspected, lubed and maintained not to mention that there are more of them which means more places for thing to break or go wrong. Also how does an eVTOL pilot cost less? They still have to be trained to the standard that the FAA requires and since they are flying a vehicle that can fly like a helicopter or an airplane, they need to have training in both, something that is certainly not cheap. Being quieter might be nice but it offers not much of a benefit. Any aircraft that is within the noise limits will work, you dont get bonus points for being quieter. And using nontraditional fuels isnt really a flex when most airports dont have the chargers for them. Also being cool doesnt mean useful. Sharks with laser eyes are cool, but not really of much benefit. Overall I see a more complex aircraft with an abysmal range, exotic requirements and not much of an opportunity for cost savings.

I dont usually have much to add on WSB but I work in hospitality IT and have to deal with these piece o sh POSs daily. The big difference in the real world with Shift4 is they want to be your credit card processor first and sell you a POS system second. They frequently give us thousands of dollars in hardware at no cost as long as we keep using them to process transactions so they get their cut. Other POSs like Simphony and Infogensis hand off CC processing to 3rd parties like Freedom Pay, Elevon, or.... Shift4. They are making some money on the hardware but mostly relying on that yearly cloud subscription for their revenue. Oracle has recently developed a CC processing software but its treated separately from the POS and not taking off well. Thats my .02.
The only moat I could see is that switching costs are high. The only way a customer is going to switch POS systems is if their current one just doesnt work.

In approximately June 2022, Federico Nannini began advising Coral Gables based MasTec Inc. MasTec about the companys proposed acquisition of Infrastructure and Energy Alternative Inc. IEA. At the time, both MasTec and IEA traded on the NASDAQ Stock Market. Immediately after, Federico Nannini began sharing confidential information about the acquisition with Mauro Nannini and Thermiotis. Federico Nannini, Thermitois, and Tonarely had attended high school together in Pinecrest, Fla. Mauro Nannini bought shares the day after Federico Nannini received access to financial information about the proposed acquisition. Thermiotis also passed the confidential acquisition information to Tonarely, shortly after Tonarely texted him I want to make some money right now . . . What we do? After Thermiotis passed the confidential information to Tonarely, he texted Not a soul okay. According to the indictment, Tonarely responded back Obviously . . . You told me not to. Days later, Tonarelys family member signed a letter sponsoring Thermiotiss membership at a Miami yacht club. As the acquisition progressed, Federico Nannini updated his father and close friend about the transaction. Thermiotis, in turn, continued to update Tonarely. At one point in July 2022, when Federico Nannini became worried the acquisition would not go through, Mauro Nannini sold his IEA stock, according to the indictment. When Federico Nannini received confidential financials that indicated the acquisition was going forward, he texted Thermiotis Its going thru . . . Holy shit bro. Thermiotis responded Dont text . . .But lfg. At that point, Mauro Nannini began to buy back his position in IEA stock and options. When MasTecs acquisition of IEA was reported publicly on July 25, 2022, Mauro Nannini, Thermiotis, and Tonarely all sold their shares and option contracts in IEA at a profit. Two days later, on July 27, 2022, Federico Nannini texted Thermiotis a picture of a Rolex Daytona, saying You wanna hook it up for the boy. I know its a little over budget but this is the one. Thermiotis responded Haahaha yeah but give it a bit . . . Prices should come down a bit on everything.

I dont know why people ignore trends. The economy is a mack truck, not a motorcycle. It doesnt turn on a dime. 5 unemployment is pretty much baked in at this point. Its going to happen at some point in the next 12 months...its not if but when. Even if the Fed cut the rates to 1 right now, wed still get there, because of the time lag of policy. The dire situation is that the Fed continues to pretend they can influence shortterm macroeconomics with decisions they make today. Like the single quarter or half point cut they deliver in September is going to do jackshit to arrest the clear trend of a rapidly declining work economy. Seriously, show my anywhere in this chart where the unemployment line starts turning up and then just smooths out or recovers without some kind of asymptotic spike. Once sentiment goes south, thats it. Fear is selfreinforcing. And were nearly there. Simply, we should have been at 45 Fed rate for the last few months, and should have been nearing a neutral rate of high 3s by the end of this year. Instead, were still severely restrictive. And at the rate the Fed wants to move, were not going to get to a neutral rate until mid2025, if not later. The dire situation will be recognized soon enough. Not everyone can see the iceberg yet. And as usual, when they do, its going to be far too late. Though on the positive side of things, I dont think itll be a particularly nasty or extended recession due to a number of positive factors, including most people being locked into low rate mortgages. Itll be shortterm economic malaise, the market will likely overfreak out, unemployment may peak around 67, and then well be back to a smooth sailing bull market. There should be some buying opportunities near the bottom though.

The door plug was removed at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, last September so that problems with some rivets could be repaired. But the necessary paperwork for that temporary door plug removal was apparently never created. So when workers replaced the door plug temporarily, other workers were unaware that bolts needed to be reinstalled, said Elizabeth Lund, senior vice president of quality for Boeing Commercial Airplanes. Ive worked at MRO facilities that help repair the planes at the airports when the airliners want to save money, instead of getting the manufacturer like embraer or boeing to repair it. There is a lack of talented blue collar workers to do the repairsinstall because they are underpaid and literally undocumented hispanic workers. The actual MODMRB engineers that do the analysis are understaffed but typically have to be on call whenever a plane is grounded. The Damage tolerance team is on call basically 247 with rotating shifts and regularly gets woken up to handle shit. There is not enough organization in documentation and SOP to do the repair according to a manual. I work in the aerospace industry and its completely believable. The amount of times things that should be traceable are not is way too often. The amount of times Ive been presented with incomplete paperwork and am told just BS it is also way too high. A lot of management at other companies just dont care because the necessary papertrail requires a ton of time and slows every aspect of production down. We get audited annually but the audits dont do any digging. They ask for a random batch of jobs and as long as everything is filled out they assume it was done properly meaning the individual process and inspection steps on the travelers are filled out and complete prior to that part moving on to the next step. People are lazy and dont care and since there is no accountability its becoming common work culture to just BS the papertrail. FAA parts have such high requirements that if a door fell off a boeing jet 5 years after it was built the FAA should be able to reach out to boeing and know within a day exactly who had hands on that part, for what step, and at exactly what time, from the first ply of material to the last nut and bolt every single aspect of the manufacturing of that part is supposed to be recording. The FAA expects to be able to point a very accurate finger at the exact person responsible for that step anytime something goes wrong. For example if I forgot to install a bolt the papertrail would say that and myself and the QA inspector responsible could potentially be sued by the FAA or criminally charged for not adhering to their policies. The fact they cant provide this is insane to me. Weve had failures that the FAA has reached out to us about and within a few minutes of pulling the paper work we are able to tell them every single piece of information they want. Its an obnoxious amount of paperwork and a real hassle but when it comes to commercial aircraft its pretty fucking necessary. The FAA needs to know which exact person in the company was responsible for the failure so they can hold that person and the company responsible.

Its called an ODA, and its a pretty standard thing throughout aviation. The FAA just isnt well funded enough to have oversight over every operation, so it delegates authority. There are individuals who are authorized to approve data DERs or entire company organizations to basically act as their own FAA ODAs. In this case, Boeing, like every big US aviation outfit, has their own ODA. Not saying its right or wrong, just that ODAs have been a thing for a long time and are standard. Source Aerospace engineer for over a decade
For things like aircraft it is necessary, too much can go wrong

This is also how the military runs as well. Hence trillions of dollars missing. We are nowhere near as safe as we think. The right person with just enough knowledge could do untold damage quite easily. We are an illusion at best.

The colored gemstone market is complex and opaque. A spot price is unrealistic in a market of such varying qualities. Its not the first time people have tried to corner a gemstone market, most fail, government regulated supply is a weak hold and product moves through with the correct connections and money. Blue Zircon can be found in many localities and white zircon can be treated. The price and comparison should also be measured against a basket of similar gem material which you will find a similar trend in pricing that many mid tier gems have moved up in value over the last several years. This last year in Tucson anecdotal discussions with gem dealers and purchasers indicated some level of inverse pricing from mine to consumers, it was more expensive material at the mine source than what was being sold in Tucson, mainly due to cash buyers paying premiums for large lots at the source. The price to reach 10K per carat is unrealistic in a lifetime term. This material is just not that rare to reach high grade ruby and sapphire pricing. if you can get 300 you are good, if you get 500 for high quality large pieces great, but the average is lower and there is a lot of material that is treated flooding the market some show up directly at the mines. A good resource on pricing and markets is GIA field Gemologist Wim Vertriest who has written many articles on sourcing stones and the market in general and has a large focus in SE Asian markets. Separately if you are looking to have large high quality pieces cut please reach out, I have some experience in faceting

Several years ago I stumbled into a weird rock market. A rock called a Saffordite was sought after by extremely eccentric people and considered very rare. Except I found an easy way to find these rocks. With a few friends we went out and mined roughly 500 lbs of these rocks and contacted a guy who sold them. He bought the whole lot from us for around 10k dollars. We went back out and mined another 200 or so lbs but when we reached back out the broker told us hed sold roughly 100 lbs of our first find before the market collapsed. Once there was a steady sales stream the interest and bidding wars for these rocks was gone. To this day saffordites sell for pennies an ounce... Thats how we single handedly crashed a rock market.

Story time I have a friend whose dad is a gem and mineral dealer. When we were in high school it wasnt his full time job or anything, it was more of a hobbyside business. But then after he retired it basically becalmed his full time jobbusiness. And let me tell you, business is booming. Ive seen some wild things while traveling in that circle of high end gem and mineral dealing. In Colorado for example, where weed is legal but the banks wont touch it, Ive seen people come in and drop 30k, 50k etc. in cash on a single tourmaline, with the intent to resell it at some point as a way to legitimize their capital. We call them Wookiees because theyre typically very hairy, and dont bathe much. Then theres the oil and gas geologists who have absurd amounts of money but dress like theyre in between hikes. Theres the HealyFealys who believe the crystals have some sort of magical properties. How they pick a rock thatll increase their Luck, or Prosperity, or bolster their love life is anyones guess. Then youve got the standard investors who are looking to diversify their wealth into collectible class assets or Asset Class Collectibles Ive heard both used. Theyre looking for something they can park their money in and resell for a profit later. You also get just collectors. People whose rock collection went way beyond what you could even fathom as a kid picking cool rocks out of a garden bed. Ive seen some specimens change hands for 7 figures or more. Truly a different world.

Hmmm. Blue zircon has a similar hardness to emerald, quartz and garnet. Fair to tough range. A lot of people say dont recommend emerald for a daily wear ring or engagement ring as can get scratched and damaged. So ..it is more preferred corundum stones and diamond for that. There are also a lot of advancements in synthetic diamonds happening now first mostly yellow, but also blue diamonds might be created. Sapphire the most famous blue stone can already be created synthetically and blue topaz as well is relatively affordable just from natural sources and a fair amount of good color tanzanite floating around. There are some that like collecting niche gemstones but that is a small part of the market compared to the jewelry industry. The name..is also a problem in that it has nothing to do with cubic zirconia, but the name zircon sounds similar so peoples perception it is a synthetic or low cost gemstone. But one of its biggest flaws in use in jewelry is that exposure to UV can turn blue zircon into an unappealing brown. That is the main reason it has not been widely adopted for jewelry. Almost a similar problem to welo opal that turns dull and yellow over time. Apatite...another blue stone that has a lovely shade can also fade and change color with UV exposure.

Most of what OP said is of course complete bullshit. Blue zircons are not the oldest gems on earth. Zircons in general, because of their small Uranium content, are used in Geology to date the rocks they are in using the UPb dating method. So they found some inherited small zircons in an Australian conglomerate that were 4.4 Ga years old. those are neither blue though nor do they have anything to do with OPs zircons. OPs zircons are less than 1 million year old and therefore very young certainly much much younger than any diamonds. In fact, you would never find natural i.e. not heat treated old, gemquality zircons. The radioactive elements in them mainly U and Th decay over time and slowly destroy the crystal lattice. All old zircons will therefore look somewhat eaten up. Blue Zircons are also neither rare nor even natural. The blue color is achieved by heating gemquality zircons which are usually yellow or orange up to about 1000degC. Zircons themselves are not rare at all either, almost every rock has some in them. Even large gemquality specimens are relatively common. Thats why you can get them for literally pennies on the internet.

Zircon itself is a very common mineral, like its everywhere in the Earths crust. Its also a terrible gemstone due to its brittleness and tendency to scratch. Weve also been able to grow and mass produce zirconscubic zirconia in a laboratory setting, which requires no slave labor, for decades now, and its becoming cheaper and more efficient year after year. There are also multiple other gemstones with similar visual qualities that are much more suitable for jewelry applications and are much cheaper, like moissanite and blue topaz. The extra stupid part of this is that there are plenty of gemstonesminerals which actually have the increasing scarcity that OP is looking for. Turquoise is a great example. It is a relatively rare semiprecious gemstone with only a handful of mines producing it in any significant quantity worldwide. Most of what you see labeled as turquoise on the market now is actually cheaper and more common stones marketed as turquoise because of how scarce real turquoise is becoming. Its basically only found in great quantities in the American southwest and the mines in the southwest have been running dry and falling short of demand for quite a while. In conclusion, I have a bachelors degree in why OP is dumb soon to be a masters!.
